"[[Dors, mon amour]]" | vote = Ten-member juries distributed 10 points among their favourite songs. | host = [[Nederlandse Televisie Stichting]] (NTS) | venue = [[Algemene Vereniging Radio Omroep|AVRO Studios]]
[[Hilversum]], Netherlands | entries = 10 | debut = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Sweden}}}} | return = None | withdraw = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|United Kingdom}}}} | null = None | interval = [[Metropole Orkest]] | opening = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y }} The '''Eurovision Song Contest 1958''' was the third [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. The contest took place in [[Hilversum]], [[Netherlands]], following the country's win at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1957|1957 Contest]], forming the convention that the winning country of the previous Eurovision Song Contest hosts the following year's contest. The event was held on Wednesday 12 March 1958 at [[Algemene Vereniging Radio Omroep|AVRO Studios]]. The winner was [[France]] with the song "[[Dors, mon amour]]", performed by [[André Claveau]], written by [[Pierre Delanoë]] and composed by [[Hubert Giraud (composer)|Hubert Giraud]]. At 46 years and 76 days of age, Claveau became the oldest victor of the contest until 1990.O'Connor, John Kennedy. The Eurovision Song Contest - The Official Celebration. Carlton Books, 2015. ISBN 978-1-78097-638-9. Pages 32-33 Ten countries participated, with [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest|Sweden]] making its début and [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest|France]] winning the contest for the first time. The United Kingdom was the first choice to stage the contest; however, following a failure to get an agreement from various artistic unions, the BBC withdrew their bid in the summer of 1957 and the United Kingdom did not enter for the second and last time to date, having also missed the first contest two years earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=250963|title=Shining a light on the United Kingdom: 60 Years at Eurovision|work=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=12 January 2017}} Along with 1956, it was the second contest (and last contest to date) that has not featured a single song in the English language. The 1958 contest continued with the policy implemented the year before where each country was limited to one song entry. This policy has been retained to date.{{cite web|title=Eurovision History – Hilversum 1958|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=275#Participants|work=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=5 March 2012}} == Location == {{details|topic=the host city|Hilversum}} [[File:522701-Studiogebouw 's-Gravelandseweg 52.jpg|thumb|left|200px|AVRO Studios, Hilversum - host venue of the 1958 contest.]] Hilversum, a municipality and a town in the province of [[North Holland]], is known as the "Media Capital" of the Netherlands. Hilversum had become the centre of broadcasting and radio in the Netherlands in the 1920s when Dutch radio company ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Nederlandse Seintoestellen Fabriek|nl}}'' settled there, and today the media sector stands as one of the top employers in the municipality of Hilversum.{{cite web|title=From Hilvertshem to Hilversum|url=http://www.hilversum.nl/Vrije_tijd_en_toerisme/Geschiedenis/Van_Hilvertshem_tot_Hilversum|publisher=Hilversum Mediastad|accessdate=23 October 2012|language=nl|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726170521/http://www.hilversum.nl/Vrije_tijd_en_toerisme/Geschiedenis/Van_Hilvertshem_tot_Hilversum|archivedate=26 July 2012|df=dmy-all}} After the establishment of the Dutch Radio Company in Hilversum in the 1920s, almost all other radio stations in the Netherlands followed suit with television following in the 1950s, thus making Hilversum at the end of the 1950s the best venue in the Netherlands to produce and broadcast such an international TV-transmitted event as the Eurovision Song Contest, while on the other hand TV was still a challenging advanced technology in general within Europe. One such media network was the host of the event, [[Nederlandse Televisie Stichting]]. The venue of the contest was the studio of AVRO (''Algemene Vereniging Radio Omroep'' or "General Association of Radio Broadcasting"), a building complex for the media's network among the media buildings within Hilversum, and which belonged to the Dutch public broadcasting association operating within the framework of the [[Netherlands Public Broadcasting|Nederlandse Publieke Omroep]] system. == Format == The contest was held in one of the Avro studio halls. The hall contained a very small stage to function as a slightly higher stand for the singers, with the program being shot from the stage floor up. Outside of frame were the microphones' and other technical devices' wires which went through the studio's lower floor at the foot of the stage. The decorative emphasis was on the stage background, the stage front and the left side from the stage from the spectator's view where the orchestra and where the performers and host's stairway entrance were located. The rear of the stage had interchangeable backgrounds for each song to add context to each song's lyrics. The centre-front of the stage, the left area from the stage with the orchestra and stairway entrance were decorated with tulips, of which the Netherlands are known for. The juries were not in the studio as in 1956. For the 1958 event, they remained in their own countries, listening to the event. Once the songs had all been sung, juries announced their results via telephone in reverse order of presentation, as in the previous year. The Italian entry was not picked up properly in some of the other countries, which meant that after all the other songs had been presented, [[Domenico Modugno]] had to perform his song again. It was the only year that the host country finished in last place until 57 years later in 2015 and again in 2018, and the first time more than one country was placed last. The interval act was music by the [[Metropole Orkest]], under the direction of maestro Dolf van der Linden. There were two interval acts, one in the middle of the competing songs performances and one after all the rest of the competing performances were shown. == Participating countries == {{Further|List of countries in the Eurovision Song Contest}} [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest|Sweden]], a country that would later be one of the most successful in the contest, debuted this year. The [[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest|United Kingdom]] decided to withdraw from the contest after initially planning to submit an entry. After the contest, the Italian entry ''"Nel Blu Dipinto Di Blu"'' (subsequently known as ''"Volare"'') by Domenico Modugno went on to become a worldwide hit. During the [[1st Grammy Awards]], held on 4 May 1959 at [[Hollywood]]'s Beverly Hilton Hotel, "Nel blu dipinto di blu" received two awards, for [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5EUaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xCUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5473,2630104&dq=grammy&hl=en|title=And Now the Grammy Awards|date=24 May 1959|author=Dornbrook, Don|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal|accessdate=1 May 2011}} The song is the only foreign-language recording to achieve this honour,{{Cite web | url = http://www.grammy.com/news/grammy-rewind-1st-annual-grammy-awards| publisher = www.grammy.com | accessdate =22 January 2012 | title = GRAMMY Rewind: 1st Annual GRAMMY Awards}} and it is the only song to have competed in the Eurovision Song Contest and received a Grammy Award.{{cite web | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=8g0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA101&dq=volare+modugno+billboard&hl=it&sa=X&ei=7iofT9jkCOan4gTlhtyyDw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=volare%20modugno%20billboard&f=false | work = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | accessdate =24 January 2012 | title = International Pull of Grammys Veries In Key Markets - Grammy Facts | date = 6 March 1999 | page =101}} The song also reached the No.1 spot in the [[Billboard (magazine)|US-American Billboard Charts]], making it one of the most successful Eurovision songs in the history of the contest. The song was also voted the second best Eurovision entry of all time at the 50th anniversary show "[[Congratulations (Eurovision)|Congratulations]]" in 2005. === Conductors === Each performance had a [[conducted|conductor]] who conducted the orchestra.[http://www.andtheconductoris.eu http://www.andtheconductoris.eu] * {{Esc|Italy}} – [[Alberto Semprini]] * {{Esc|Netherlands}} – [[Dolf van der Linden]] * {{Esc|France}} – [[Franck Pourcel]] * {{Esc|Luxembourg}} – Dolf van der Linden * {{Esc|Sweden}} – Dolf van der Linden * {{Esc|Denmark}} – Kai Mortensen * {{Esc|Belgium}} – Dolf van der Linden * {{Esc|Germany}} – Dolf van der Linden * {{Esc|Austria}} – Willy Fantl * {{Esc|Switzerland}} – [[Paul Burkhard]] === Returning artists === Four artists who had participated in previous editions of the contest returned in 1958: Fud Leclerc, who also represented Belgium in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1956|1956]]; Margot Hielscher for Germany, who also participated in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1957|1957]]; Corry Brokken for the Netherlands, who participated in 1956 and won in 1957; and Lys Assia, who won the first contest in 1956 and participated in 1957. == Results == {| class="sortable wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" ! '''History Live''' (formerly '''The festival of history''') is an annual summer event held by [[English Heritage]]. The event focusses on [[historical re-enactment]]. The first event was held in 2003 and attracted 10,000 visitors, and since then has been held annually in July or August in the grounds of [[Stoneleigh Park]] in [[Warwickshire]] (2003 and 2004) or [[Kelmarsh Hall]] in [[Northamptonshire]] (2005 onwards). It is Europe's biggest historical event.<ref name=C2409>{{cite news|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%26+heritage/work+%26+daily+life/art69827|title=Get ready for the English Heritage Festival of History 2009|date=2009-06-25|accessdate=2011-07-07|work=Culture 24}}</ref>
==Aims== English Heritage is the executive non-departmental public body of the British Government sponsored by the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] which is responsible for the historic built environment in the UK. Public education on the history of England is a large part of the body's remit. English Heritage describes the Festival of History as its "flagship event"<ref name=EHAR08-09>{{cite web|title=English Heritage Annual Report and Accounts 2008-09| url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/content/publications/docs/Annual_Report_and_Accounts_0809.pdf |work=[[English Heritage]]| date=2008 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> and the "highlight of its event calendar".<ref name=EHDO>{{cite news|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/|title=Days out in England|accessdate=2011-07-07|work=[[English Heritage]]}}</ref>
Events include historical re-enactments involving several thousand people in all, aerial displays, demonstrations, specialist talks, story-telling, theatre and hands-on events for children.<ref name=EHWO11>{{cite news|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/events/foh-2011/whats-on-2011/|title=What's On 2011|accessdate=2011-07-07|work=[[English Heritage]]}}</ref>
==History== ===At [[Stoneleigh Park]]=== * 2003, 9-10 August, 10,000 visitors. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821213504/http://www.msportuk.com/news/2003/q3/20030708_history_fest.php |archivedate=2008-08-21 |df= }}</ref><ref name=H&H03>{{cite web |title=Celebrate horses through history |url=http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/397/40976.html |work=[[Horse and Hound]] |first=Holly |last=Kirkwood |date=2003-08-06 |accessdate=2011-07-07 |deadurl=yes name=EHAR04-05>{{cite web|title=English Heritage Annual Report and Accounts 2004-05| url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/content/publications/docs/Annual_Report0405.pdf |work=[[English Heritage]]| date=2005 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref><ref name=PAS04>{{cite web|title=Portable Antiquities at the English Heritage Festival of History |url=http://finds.org.uk/news/stories/article/id/130 |work=[[Portable Antiquities Scheme]] |date=2004-08-17 |accessdate=2011-07-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202070004/http://finds.org.uk/news/stories/article/id/130 url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/content/publications/docs/annual-report-and-accounts-0910.pdf |work=[[English Heritage]]| date=2007 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> Set piece re-enactments: The [[Siege of Harfleur]];<ref name=HM09>{{cite web|title=Battle lines drawn for festival fun|url=http://www.harboroughmail.co.uk/lifestyle/battle_lines_drawn_for_festival_fun_1_1536803|work=[[Harborough Mail]]| date=2009-07-24 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> the [[Battle of Agincourt]];<ref name=C2409b>{{cite news|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%26+heritage/art70608|title=Families go name=HM09/><ref name=C2409b/> *2010, 17-18 July.<ref name=BCT10>{{cite web|title=English Heritage – Festival of History 2010 |url=http://birminghamconservationtrust.org/2010/07/17/english-heritage-festival-of-history-2010/|work=[[Birmingham Conservation Trust]]|first=Emma|last=Neil| date=2010-07-17 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> *2012, Arranged for 14-15 July. Due to torrential rain & flooding in the early hours of Saturday morning it had to be cancelled.
==2011 event== The 2011 event on 16 and 17 July 2011 at Kelmarsh Hall includes re-enactments of the [[Imperial Roman army|Imperial Roman Army]] and [[Gladiator|gladiatorial]] fighting; armoured knights and medieval [[jousting]]; a display of "[[Tent pegging|tent-pegging]]", a medieval Indian sport;<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|title=Tent-pegging sees taxi drivers swap cars for horses| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-14053996 |work=[[BBC]] online| date=2011-07-06|accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> the [[Duke of Wellington's Regiment|Duke of Wellington's redcoats]]; a Victorian [[gymkhana]]; a replica [[World War I]] trench<ref name=C2410>{{cite news|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%26+heritage/war+%26+conflict/world+war+one/art359777|title=War Horse heads to English Heritage Festival of History for dramatic World War I trench recreation|date=2010-07-06|accessdate=2011-07-07|first=Richard|last=Moss|work=Culture 24}}</ref> and [[World War II]] action including a [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] flypast. As well as re-enactments there are family activities and sideshows.<ref name=EHWO11/>
2011 sees the inaugural ''Festival of Historical Writing'' at the event, in partnership with [[the Historical Writers' Association]]. Guest speakers include [[Michael Morpurgo]], the author of ''[[War Horse (novel)|War Horse]]'', and [[Manda Scott]].<ref name=HWA>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehwa.co.uk/content/festivals |title=Festivals |accessdate=2011-07-07 |work=Historical Writers' Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628034726/http://www.thehwa.co.uk/content/festivals |archivedate=2011-06-28 |df= }}</ref>
==History Live!== In 2014, the event was renamed History Live! and was still held at Kelmarsh Hall. In February 2015, English Heritage announced there would be no History Live! in 2015 stating "History Live! will not be returning this year, in order to concentrate on delivering a wider range of events across England."<ref>http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/about-us/search-news/2015-events-programme</ref>

page.title: Forbidden City: Portrait of An Empress

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Forbidden City: Portrait of an Empress''''' is a Singapore Musical that tells the story of China's Legendary [[Empress Dowager Cixi]]. It was staged by the [[Singapore Repertory Theatre]] originally on 17-19 October 2002 at the Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay, as part of its opening festival, and back again in 2003 by popular demand and in 2006 as part of the IMF meetings in Singapore. It will have a world tour in 2008. Forbidden City was developed by Stephen Clark, Dick Lee and [[Steven Dexter]]. 15 years from its premiere, it was staged once again on Aug 2017 back at the Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay.
==2006 Cast==
*[[Andrew Lua]] (Ensemble) *[[Candice de Rozario]] (Ensemble) *[[Cedric Lim]] (Ensemble) *[[Celine Rosa Tan]] (Yehanara Alternate/Ensemble) *[[Cynthia Lee MacQuarrie]] (Curator/Ensemble) *[[Dillon Ong]] (Kuang Hsu, 9 years old) *[[Dunstan Ong]] (Ensemble) *[[Dwayne Tan]] (Kuang Hsu) *[[Edric Hsu]] (Ensemble) *[[Eleanor Tan]] (Ensemble) *[[Farhan Hassan]] (Ensemble) *[[George Chan (actor)|George Chan]] (Prince Tun) *[[Gordon Choy]] (Ensemble) *Hal Fowler (George Morrison) *[[Hossan Leong]] (Record Keeper 1) *Jacqueline Pereira (Ensemble) *[[Joanna Dong]] (Ensemble) *[[Joel Ng]] (Tung Chih, 4 years old) *[[Jovan Lee]] (Tung Chih, 4 years old) *[[Juliet Pang]] (Ensemble) *[[Kaylen Chan]] (Tung Chih/Ensemble) *[[Kit Chan]] (Yehenara) *[[Leigh McDonald]] (Kate Carl) *[[Luke Kwek]] (Kuang Hsu, 15 years old/Ensemble) *[[Ng Kit Chong]] (Kuang Hsu, 9 years old) *[[Oliver Pang]] (Emperor/Ensemble) *[[Presslee Chng]] (Tung Chih, 4 years old) *[[RJ Rosales]] (Prince Tuan) *[[Richard Chia]] (Grand Eunuch/Ensemble) *[[Russell Marino Soh]] (Kuang Hsu, 9 years old) *[[Sebastian Tan]] (Record Keeper 2) *[[Seong Hui Xuan]] (Ensemble) *[[Sheila Francisco]] (Empress Dowager)
==Synopsis==
===Act One===
Kate Carl, an American artist, is invited to paint the portrait of the Empress of China, Cixi. When she arrives in China she hears many rumours about the Empress. She also meets George Morrison, an English journalist on the train to Beijing. He tells her not to be intimidated by the rumours that they heard from the locals. After meeting the Empress, she was asked by the Empress when the work on the portrait can begin. Kate then tells her that she must know her before painting the portrait as art is a two way process. The empress is then suspicious of her at first, but begins her story which unfolds back fifty years ago when she was a young girl...
The empress who was known as Yehernara as a young girl, yearns to become the Emperor's escort after the then empress was pregnant. As was the custom, the Emperor would start to look for a new escort. Yehenara desperately wanted to be chosen by the Emperor to be his escort, and she was indeed chosen. After three months, she was pregnant and the emperor started choosing yet another escort. Yehernara was then taken to the Summer Palace as it was said to be the best place to give birth to a child, where she gave birth to a son, Tung Chih. This was the Emperor's first son and was very important to the dynasty. However, as was the custom, the baby was taken away from Yehenara to be brought up by the court.
Prince Tun, the emperor's scheming brother was devastated by the birth of Tung Chih as he had plans to take the throne for himself. However, whilst still at the Summer Palace, the British attacked and destroyed the Palace. The Royal party fled to the Winter Palace. By then, the Emperor was becoming very weak and was dying. Yehenara knew that if he died without naming Tung Chih as his heir, Prince Tun would claim the throne and her son's and her life would be in grave danger. She was prevented from finding her son so that Prince Tun would be the next Emperor but she found her son and rushed to the Emperor's chamber. No one could stop her while she was carrying the Emperor's son. With his last breath, the Emperor named Tung Chih as his successor and Yehenara as Regent.
===Act Two===
A few years later, Tung Chih grew up to be a rebellious young man. He was tempted by Prince Tuan, the son of Prince Tun, to go to the brothels. Indulging in his new-found freedom he became ill with syphilis. Yehenara was helpless to do anything but wipe his feverish brow with her handkerchief as he died. Again Prince Tun saw a chance for power but was thwarted as Yehenara quickly named her nephew, Kuang Hsu, as the next Emperor.
All this time Kate writes to Morrison about all these events. He is amazed that the Empress is being so open and notes that the stories the Empress has told Kate contradict all the rumours he has heard. After that he wonders how he is going to write a book on the Empress. Meanwhile, the story continues...
She tells Kate that Kuang Hsu became an ambitious Emperor, determined to reform China. But this led to the [[Boxer Rebellion]] and China was crippled by the internal conflict. Despite everything Yehenara has tried to do, she is surrounded by loss and failure.
Kate meets with Morrison. She is falling in love and Morrison continues to be fascinated by everything she tells him about the Empress. The day arrives when Kate is to show the Empress the completed portrait, but the Empress was furious as a newspaper stated her to be very evil to the extent that she killed Tung Chih with a smallpox laden handkerchief. She thought that Kate has betrayed her, but Kate then finds out Morrison has betrayed her instead and the reason is to get a bigger market for opium in China as the opium war didn't do the trick.
After learning the truth, Kate was devastated as she had fallen in love in Morrison. The story then draws to a close and Kate was back in the museum and the people had started to stream in. After seeing the portrait, the people continues their thinking of Empress Cixi as a dragon lady. Even though Kate tries hard to tell her story, nobody wants to listen. The musical ends with both Yehernara and the Empress looking at the portrait and telling her that their real story has been told.
==Songs==
*Dragon Lady *Why The Forbidden City *Starting With The Eyes *My Only Chance *I Need Him, Falling In Love *Summer Palace *Now China Has A Son *The Land of Our Fathers *Gentle Touch *Blood in the Streets *Why Dream of Love (New song added in 2003) *Stories *My Only Chance (Reprise) *Why Dream Of Love (Reprise) *Stories (Reprise)
==Differences between the three runs==
Some scenes were being altered or deleted as the musical was being extended so as to attract more people to watch it. *In the original run (2002), Prince Tuan was shot dead but in 2003 and 2006, Prince Tun was the one being shot. *In 2002, Prince Tun was telling the empress to allow him to lead a battle else the allied troops launch an attack after dusk. But in 2003 and 2006, it was Yehernara as there was another song to be sung by her, Why Dream of Love, which was added in 2003. *In 2002, it did not show the stages where Kuang Hsu were growing up, but in 2003 and 2006, there were a scene where Kuang Hsu was reading a book when he was a little boy, before becoming a teenager and finally, an adult.
'''Credits'''
Information obtained from Singapore Repertory Theatre. The making of Forbidden City can be found at the SRT website.
==External links== * Website at: http://www.srt.com.sg

{{Update| date = March 2017}} {{Infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Hangout Music Festival | image = [[File:Hangout Fest, 2013.jpg|240px]] | location = 101 East Beach Boulevard
[[Gulf Shores, Alabama|Gulf Shores]], [[Alabama]], USA | years_active= 2010–present | genre = [[rock music|Rock]], [[alternative rock|alternative]], [[electronic dance music]], [[Indie rock|indie]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], [[jam bands]], [[reggae]] | website = [http://hangoutmusicfest.com/ Official website]}} The '''Hangout Music Festival''' (commonly referred to as '''Hangout Fest''' or '''Hangout''') is an annual three-day [[music festival]] held at the public beaches of [[Gulf Shores, Alabama|Gulf Shores]] directly accompanying its sister restaurant [[The Hangout|The Hangout (Restaurant)]].{{cite web |url=http://www.hangoutmusicfest.com/about/ |title=About Hangout Fest |publisher=Hangout Music Festival |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.southernliving.com/travel/south-central/gulf-shores-hangout-music-festival-00417000073243/ |title=Hangout Music Festival |author=Amy Bickers |work=Southern Living |publisher=Time Inc. Lifestyle Group |accessdate=July 20, 2011}} The festival is produced by Sean O'Connell in partnership with [[Goldenvoice]]. O'Connell, who has been involved in Hangout since its inception, became director of the festival in 2013.{{Cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/life/entertainment/12th/2016/04/25/nas-bringyourbrave-0426/83511038/|title=Hang out with the man behind Gulf Shores music fest|work=The Tennessean|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/05/hangout_music_fest_director_ex.html|title=Hangout Music Fest director: Expect 'very noticeable' changes at event|work=AL.com|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.pnj.com/story/entertainment/festivals/hangout-fest/2015/02/16/hangout-fest-director-discusses-year-vibe/23525233/|title=Exclusive: Hangout Fest director discusses year 6 vibe|work=Pensacola News Journal|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en}} The event features many [[Music genre|genres of music]], including [[rock music|rock]], [[Indie rock|indie]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], and [[electronic dance music]]. The main stages are the Hangout Stage and the Surf Stage (located on opposite ends of the beach), as well as the Boom Boom Tent and more.{{Cite news|url=https://www.lsionline.com/news/bandit-on-the-beach-for-hangout-festival|title=Bandit on the beach for Hangout festival|last=Sonja|work=LSi Online|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en-gb}} The festival generally takes place on the third weekend in May. It is the first major music festival held on the beach in the city.{{cite web |url=http://www.discoveralabamabeaches.com/the-hangout-music-festival/ |title=The Hangout Beach, Music & Arts Festival |publisher=Discover Alabama Beaches |accessdate=July 20, 2011}} Notable acts that have performed at Hangout Fest include [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Paul Simon]], [[Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[OutKast]], [[Mumford & Sons]], [[The Weeknd]], [[The Killers]], [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]], [[Dave Matthews Band]], [[Twenty One Pilots]], [[Kings of Leon]], [[Queens of the Stone Age]], [[Florence and the Machine]], [[The Black Keys]], [[Widespread Panic]], [[Paramore]], [[Ellie Goulding]], [[The Avett Brothers]] and [[Chance the Rapper]]. Acts such as the [[Trey Anastasio|Trey Anastasio Band]], [[The Flaming Lips]], [[Moon Taxi]], and [[Bassnectar]] have performed several times at the festival. ==Background== [[File:GulfShoresAlBeachJuly08B altered.jpg|thumb|The beaches of [[Gulf Shores, Alabama|Gulf Shores]], [[Alabama]] in 2007.]] Hangout Music Festival was founded in November 2009 by A.J. Niland, Shaul and Lilly Zislin.{{Cite news|url=https://www.houstonpress.com/music/the-sights-and-sounds-of-hangout-music-fest-2015-7446354|title=A Trip To Hangout Fest 2015|work=Houstonpress.com|access-date=2018-11-25|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.southernliving.com/culture/hangout-fest-a-look-behind-the-scenes-with-co-founder-lily-zislin|title=Hangout Fest: A Look Behind The Scenes With Co-Founder Lilly Zislin|work=Southern Living|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en}} The Zislins are the proprietors of "The Hangout", the festival's namesake restaurant.{{cite news |author=Ryan Dezember|title=In Gulf Shores, Plan B looks like a winner for Hangout developer|date=January 24, 2010 |url=http://blog.al.com/live/2010/01/in_gulf_shores_plan_b_looks_li.html |newspaper=[[Press-Register]] |accessdate=July 20, 2011}} The festival received approval from the Gulf Shores city council in December 2009, as well as a permit for acts to perform an hour later than would normally be allowed under city noise laws.{{cite news |author=Ryan Dezember|title=Music festival in Gulf Shores gets approval from city council |date=December 15, 2009 |url=http://blog.al.com/live/2009/12/music_festival_on_gulf_shores.html |newspaper=[[Press-Register]] |accessdate=July 20, 2011}} Lilly Zislin is the creative director of the festival Shortly before the festival's opening, the Gulf Coast was hit by the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]], which impacted its attendance and general public perception of the area. The festival was attended by 13,000–15,000 people per day in 2010.{{cite news |author=Mark Hughes Cobb|title=Hangout Music Fest brings thousands to Gulf Coast |date=May 18, 2012|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20120518/ent/120519768 |newspaper=[[The Tuscaloosa News]] |accessdate=July 20, 2011}} Attendance in 2011 had to be capped at 35,000 per day, an unprecedented number for the second year of a music festival in the region, due to safety concerns.{{cite web |url=http://www.fox10tv.com/dpp/news/local_news/baldwin_county/gulf-shores-preps-for-music-festival |title=Gulf Shores preps for music festival |author=Libby Amos |date=May 13, 2011 |publisher=Fox 10 ([[WALA-TV]]) |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite news |title=Hangout Music Festival, Day 1: Beautiful weather, beautiful venue, epic performances (photos, video) |author=Lawrence F. Specker |url=http://blog.al.com/entertainment-press-register/2011/05/hangout_music_festival_day_1_b.html |newspaper=Press-Register |date=May 20, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.luminomagazine.com/mw/content/view/3228/1 |title=Hangout Fest: Perfection on the Beach |author=Hilary Cadigan |date=July 19, 2011 |publisher=Lumino Magazine |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite news |title=Hangout Festival brings millions of dollars to coast |author=Associated Press |url=http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20110627/NEWS02/106270315/Hangout-Festival-brings-millions-dollars-coast |newspaper=Montgomery Advertiser |date=June 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60KZUuPgi |archivedate=July 20, 2011 |deadurl=no}} The 2011 event was estimated to have generated approximately $30 million for the Gulf Shores area economy. Advance tickets for the 2012 event, which continues to be capped at 35,000 attendees per day, sold out within one hour.{{cite news |title=Hangout Music Festival advance tickets sell out in first hour; regular-priced tickets remain |author=Matt Cuthbert |url=http://blog.al.com/gulf-coast/2012/02/tickets_for_hangout_music_fest.html |newspaper=AL.com |date=February 10, 2012 |accessdate=May 11, 2012}} General admission tickets sold out on February 21, 2012, almost three months prior to the event.{{cite news |title=Hangout Music Fest general admission sells out, some VIP tickets remain |author=Dennis Pillion |url=http://blog.al.com/gulf-coast/2012/02/hangout_music_fest_general_adm.html |newspaper=AL.com |date=February 21, 2012 |accessdate=May 11, 2012}} The 2013 festival sold out as well, but failed to meet the previous year's "rapid sellout" of general admission tickets.{{cite news |title=Hangout Music Fest founder Zislin: 2013 edition will be full of surprises|author= Lawrence Specker|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2013/05/hangout_music_fest_founder_zis_1.html|newspaper=[[Press-Register]] |date=May 14, 2013 |accessdate=May 18, 2014}} 40,000 tickets were sold in 2014, up from the previous audience cap of 35,000.{{cite news |title=Hangout Music Fest director: Expect 'very noticeable' changes at event |author= Lawrence Specker|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/05/hangout_music_fest_director_ex.html|newspaper=[[Press-Register]] |date=May 9, 2014 |accessdate=May 18, 2014}} In 2014, the festival first allowed access to the [[Gulf of Mexico]], which was previously restricted to security and artists.{{cite news |title=Hangout Fest looks to add splash in 2014 with access to Gulf of Mexico |author= Marc D. Anderson|url=http://blog.al.com/live/2014/02/hangout_fest_looks_to_add_spla.html|newspaper=[[Press-Register]] |date=February 21, 2014 |accessdate=May 18, 2014}} In 2015, [[Goldenvoice]], the company behind [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]], entered into a joint venture to produce Hangout Fest.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/13/business/media/coachella-organizers-in-deal-with-hangout-music-festival.html|title=Coachella Organizers in Deal With Hangout Music Festival|author=Ben Sisario|date=January 12, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=January 12, 2015}} == Economic Impact == The city receives over $700,000 in direct tax revenue each year http://local15tv.com/news/local/gulf-shores-makes-ready-for-hangout-fest-kickoff plus a franchise fee of one percent of gross festival ticket revenue beginning with the 2017 festival, and increasing to three percent in 2019.http://www.al.com/news/beaches/index.ssf/2014/10/hangout_fest_assembly_permit_e.html In 2014, the festival signed a 10 year agreement with the city to continue through at least 2020. A study conducted in 2013 by M. [[Keivan Deravi]], a professor of economics at [[Auburn University]], shows that the festival infuses over $31 million dollars into the local economy and reaches an estimated 564 million through social media, TV outlets and live-streaming video of the event.{{Cite news|url=http://blog.al.com/live/2013/12/hangout_festival_injects_31_mi.html|title=Hangout Festival injects $31 million into local economy, study finds|work=AL.com|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en-US}} The 2014 festival was projected to have a $47.5 million dollar impact {{Cite news|url=http://www.al.com/news/mobile/index.ssf/2014/06/stage_set_in_gulf_shores_for_h.html|title=Stage set in Gulf Shores for vote on Hangout Fest 5-year permit renewal; surveys, talks reveal support|work=AL.com|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en-US}} == Recognition == The festival has been nominated multiple times for "Festival of the Year" at the concert industry's Pollstar Awards https://www.pollstarpro.com/live2016/Awards/awardscategories.htmlhttps://www.pollstar.com/article/2011-pollstar-awards-nominees-announced-21716 and won the award in 2012.http://www.hangoutmusicfest.com/wp-content/uploads/Hangout-Pollstar-FINAL.pdf The festival has been nominated multiple times for "Festival of the Year" at the IEBA awards.http://www.iavm.org/2017-ieba-industry-award-nominees-announced-many-are-iavm-membershttp://ampthemag.com/the-real/ieba-industry-award-nominees-announced/ ==Performers== {{further|Hangout Music Festival line-ups}} ===2010=== The inaugural Hangout Beach Festival was held on May 14–16, 2010.
