[[File:Gramado rua.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Natal Luz]] '''Natal Luz''', which literally means “Christmas of Lights”, is an annual Christmas festivity in Gramado, [[Brazil]].<ref>[http://www.natalluzdegramado.com.br/pt/home/natal-luz-gramado.php Official Website of the Festival] Retrieved 11 January 2011</ref> The festival began in 1986 as a small concert conducted by [[Eleazar de Carvalho]], one of the country’s most celebrated orchestra conductors. Over the years, it has grown into Brazil’s largest Christmas event.<ref>Weller, Diane. “Christmas in Brazil: A Magnificent Celebration of Light.”Ornamentshop.com.http://www.ornamentshop.com/xmas_trivia/christmas_traditions_in_brazil.asp Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref>
The Natal Luz is celebrated in Gramado, a city in Rio Grande do Sul. [[Gramado]] has been labeled the country’s Christmas capital, an honor it has held for over 20 years. The celebration gathers around 1.5 million people every year <ref>Evans, Jess. “W-DMX Joins Natal Luz Gramado Party.” LSi Online.http://www.lsionline.co.uk/news/story/W-DMX-joins-Natal-Luz-Gramado-party/-A4F4XF Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> and runs from November 12 to January 13,<ref>Cutting, Leo. “Gramado, Brazil’s Christmas Capital.” The Rio Times.http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/rio-travel/exploring-gramado-brazils-christmas-capital/ Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> making it one of the longest [[Christmas]] festivals in the world.
==Highlights and Attractions== The celebration of the Natal Luz consists of a wide array of events and attractions,<ref>Weller, Diane. “Christmas in Brazil: A Magnificent Celebration of Light.”Ornamentshop.com Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> including one that allows visitors to feel how it is to be inside a Christmas tree. The so-called magic Christmas tree is 99-foot tall and has over 3,500 ornaments, 2,600 string lights, 1,000 strobe lights, and an artificial snow machine. The festivities also include tree lighting shows, contests, games, parades, reindeer exhibits, musical performances, and dramatic readings of classic holiday plays, such as the “Fantastic Christmas Factory”, a musical about a child who was able to witness the wonders of Christmas coming to life.
One of the most anticipated events of the Natal Luz is the Nativitaten.<ref>Lima, Leandra. “Gramado: Natal Luz IluminaAsRuas de Cidade(Natal Luz Lights Up Gramado Streets).”O Globo.Boa Viagem.http://oglobo.globo.com/boa-viagem/gramado-natal-luz-ilumina-as-ruas-da-cidade-6748372 Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> Held at the center of the Joaquina Rita Bier Lake, the celebration involves a floating lights show, a performance by choirs, tenors, sopranos, and Brazil’s musicians as well as circus acts, amid a display of fireworks . The performance is usually divided into five acts, which depict the journey of mankind throughout history, from the creation of the world, the birth of Jesus Christ, the coming of darkness, all the way through to the day of salvation.
Another event people look forward to is the Tannenbaumfest,<ref>[http://www.natalluzdegramado.com.br/pt/home/natal-luz-gramado.php Official Website of the Festival] Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> where local Gramado business owners compete to create the most beautiful Christmas tree in the city. The trees are placed in the Avenida Borges de Medeiros for everyone to see. The decorated trees are evaluated by a panel of judges, and the winners are announced at an awarding ceremony in December. The trees are left on display until the end of the Natal Luz. There have also been special events during this three-month festival. The most notable of these happened in 2009, when 2,000 of the city’s inhabitants worked hand-in-hand to create a jigsaw puzzle made from a million lamps.<ref>Baldussi, Davi. “Christmas in Gramado.”The Rio Times.http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/rio-travel/christmas-in-gramado/ Retrieved 17 May 2013</ref> The jigsaw puzzle completion was celebrated with a pyrotechnic display, which used over 10,000 fireworks.
==See also== *[[List of classical music festivals in South America]] *[[List of music festivals in Brazil]] * [[Christmas lights in Medellín]]

page.title: Osama bin Laden death conspiracy theories

revision.comment: Made a small wording edit on Burial at sea
revision.text:
The [[death of Osama bin Laden]] gave rise to various [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]], [[hoax]]es, and rumors.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-bin-laden-conspiracy-20110503,0,3052618.story|title=Osama bin Laden dead: Bin Laden's burial at sea fuels 'death hoax' rumor|publisher=latimes.com | first1=Matea|last1=Gold|first2=David S.|last2=Cloud|first3=Eryn|last3=Brown|date=May 3, 2011}}</ref> These include the ideas that bin Laden had been dead for years, or is still alive. Doubts about bin Laden's death were fueled by the U.S. military's supposed disposal of his body at sea,<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.us/newyork/international/article/848817--osama-bin-laden-conspiracy-theories-thrive-on-lack-of-proof|title=Osama bin Laden: Conspiracy theories thrive on lack of proof|author=Alison Bowen|publisher=Metro}}</ref> the decision to not release any photographic or DNA evidence of bin Laden's death to the public,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/09/28/us_bin_laden_photos/|title=US tells court bin Laden photos must stay secret|author=Richard Lardner|publisher=Associated Press|location=Washington|date=Sep 28, 2011}}</ref> the contradicting accounts of the incident (with the official story on the raid appearing to change or directly contradict previous assertions),<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/04/osama-bin-laden-killing-us-story-change|title=The killing of Osama bin Laden: how the White House changed its story|author=Robert Booth|publisher=Guardian|location=London|date=May 4, 2011}}</ref> and the 25-minute blackout during the raid on bin Laden's compound during which a live feed from cameras mounted on the helmets of the U.S. special forces was cut off.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/al-qaeda/8493391/Osama-bin-Laden-dead-Blackout-during-raid-on-bin-Laden-compound.html.|title=Osama bin Laden dead: Blackout during raid on bin Laden compound|author=Swinford, Steven|publisher=Telegraph|location=London|date=May 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/doubts-grow-on-us-version-of-strike-against-bin-laden-20110505-1eaah.html|title=Doubts grow on US version of strike against bin Laden|author=Steven Swinford|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref>
On May 1, 2011, an image purporting to show a dead bin Laden was broadcast on Pakistani television. Although the story was picked up by much of the British press, as well the [[Associated Press]], it was swiftly removed from websites after it was exposed as a fake on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/02/osama-bin-laden-photo-fake|title=Osama bin Laden corpse photo is fake|author=Amelia Hill|publisher=Guardian|location=London|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://militarytimes.com/blogs/battle-rattle/2011/05/02/bin-laden-death-photo-fake|title=Bin Laden death photo: FAKE!|publisher=MilitaryTimes}}</ref>
On May 4, the [[Obama administration]] announced it would not release any images of Bin Laden's dead body.<ref>Montopoli, Brian (2011-05-04). "[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20059739-503544.html?tag=breakingnews Obama: I won't release bin Laden death photos]." ''[[CBS News]]''. Retrieved 2011-05-04.</ref> The administration had considered releasing the photos to dispel rumors of a hoax, at the risks of perhaps prompting another attack by [[al Qaeda]] and of releasing very graphic images to people who might find them disturbing.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=telegraph2>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/8500635/Osama-bin-Laden-killed-live.html|title=Osama bin Laden killed: live coverage|publisher=Telegraph | location=London}}</ref> Several photos of the aftermath of the raid were given to [[Reuters]] by an anonymous Pakistani security official, but though all appeared to be authentic, they were taken after the U.S. forces had left and none of them included evidence regarding bin Laden's fate.<ref>{{cite news | first = Chris | last = Allbritton |author2=John Boyle | title = Photos show three dead men at bin Laden raid house | date = 4 May 2011 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/04/us-binladen-pakistan-photos-idUSTRE7437KK20110504 | work = [[Reuters]] | accessdate = 2013-02-12}}</ref>
On May 6, it was reported that an al-Qaeda website acknowledged bin Laden's death.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2011/05/al-qaeda-confirms-osama-bin-ladens-death-in-internet-statement/1|title=Al-Qaeda confirms bin Laden's death, threatens new attacks|author=Douglas Stanglin|publisher=USA Today|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> On May 11, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] senator and [[Senate Armed Services Committee]] member [[Jim Inhofe]] stated he had viewed "gruesome" photographs of bin Laden's corpse, and later confirmed that the body "was him", adding, "He's history".<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/05/11/congress.bin.laden.photos/index.html?hpt=T1 Members of Congress see bin Laden photos], CNN.com, May 11, 2011</ref>
On May 21, 2015, journalist [[Seymour Hersh]] [[Seymour Hersh#Death of Osama bin Laden|published a report]]<ref name="Seymour M. Hersh">{{cite journal | url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n10/seymour-m-hersh/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden | title=The Killing of Osama bin Laden | author=Seymour M. Hersh | journal=London Review of Books}}</ref> claiming that Pakistan had kept bin Laden under house arrest since 2006, that the U.S. had learned of bin Laden's location through a Pakistani intelligence official and not through tracking a courier,<ref name=hersh /><ref name=intercepthersh>{{cite news|last1=Schwarz|first1=Jon|last2=Devereaux|first2=Ryan|title=CLAIM: SY HERSH’S BIN LADEN STORY IS TRUE — BUT OLD NEWS|url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/05/11/former-professor-reported-basics-hershs-bin-laden-story-2011-seemingly-different-sources/|accessdate=12 May 2015|agency=The Intercept|date=12 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=NBChersh>{{cite news|last1=Cole|first1=Matthew|last2=Esposito|first2=Richard|last3=Windrem|first3=Robert|last4=Mitchell|first4=Andrea|title=Pakistanis Knew Where Osama Bin Laden Was, U.S. Sources Say|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/pakistanis-knew-where-bin-laden-was-say-us-sources-n357306|accessdate=12 May 2015|agency=NBC News|publisher=NBC News|date=11 May 2015}}</ref> and that elements of the Pakistani military aided the U.S. in killing bin Laden.<ref name=hersh>{{cite news|last1=Hersh|first1=Seymour|title=The Killing of Osama bin Laden|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n10/seymour-m-hersh/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden|accessdate=11 May 2015|agency=The London Review of Books|publisher=The London Review of Books|date=21 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Independent">{{cite news|title=Osama Bin Laden was an unarmed elderly 'invalid' when Navy Seals killed him and Barack Obama lied about the mission, report claims|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/osama-bin-laden-was-an-unarmed-elderly-invalid-when-navy-seals-killed-him-and-barack-obama-lied-about-the-mission-report-claims-10241635.html|accessdate=11 May 2015|publisher=The Independent|date=11 May 2015}}</ref> The White House denied Hersh's report.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite news|title=White House dismisses new Osama bin Laden raid claims|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11597928/White-House-dismisses-new-Osama-bin-Laden-raid-claims.html|accessdate=11 May 2015|publisher=Telegraph|date=11 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news|title=‘Utter nonsense': CIA and White House blast Seymour Hersh's explosive Osama bin Laden raid story |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/05/11/utter-nonsense-cia-and-white-house-blast-explosive-osama-bin-laden-raid-story/|accessdate=11 May 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=11 May 2015}}</ref>
==Lack of physical evidence== The primary source of skepticism about the U.S. government's story has been its own refusal to provide any physical evidence to substantiate its claim. Although the Abbottabad raid has been described in great detail by U.S. officials, no physical evidence constituting actual proof of his death has been offered to the public, neither to journalists nor to independent third parties who have requested this information through the [[Freedom of Information Act]] (FOIA).<ref name="FOIA1">{{cite news|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2011/05/associated-press-case-releasing-bin-laden-photo/37510/|title=The Associated Press's Case for Releasing the Bin Laden Photo|author=John Hudson|publisher=The Atlantic Wire|date=May 10, 2011}}</ref> Numerous organizations filed FOIA requests seeking at least a partial release of photographs, videos, and/or DNA test results, including [[The Associated Press]], [[Reuters]], [[CBS News]], [[Judicial Watch]], [[Politico]], [[Fox News]], [[Citizens United (organization)|Citizens United]], and [[NPR]].<ref name="FOIA2">{{cite news|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/politics/2011/05/look-whos-foiaing-bin-laden-death-photo/37493/|title=A Look at Who's FOIAing the Bin Laden Death Photo|author=John Hudson|publisher=The Atlantic Wire|date=May 9, 2011}}</ref> At the time of filing their FOIA request, The Associated Press said: {{Quote|text=This information is important for the historical record. That's our view.|sign=Michael Oreskes, Senior Managing Editor, The Associated Press<ref name="FOIA1"/>}}
On April 26, 2012, a US federal judge decided in the case ''Judicial Watch v. U.S. Department of Defense, et al'' that the DoD did not need to release any evidence to the public.
==Burial at sea== Doubts about bin Laden's death were fueled by the U.S. military's disposal of his body at sea, though U.S. officials maintained that the burial was necessary because arrangements could not be made with any country to bury bin Laden within 24 hours, as dictated by [[Islamic funeral|Muslim practice]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> The Muslim practice has not always been followed by the U.S. in the past. For example, the bodies of [[Uday Hussein]] and [[Qusay Hussein]], sons of [[Saddam Hussein]], were held for 11 days before being released for burial.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/02/bin-laden-body-buried-sea|title=Bin Laden's body buried at sea|author=Brian Whitaker|publisher=Guardian|location=London|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> In that instance, however, several Iraqi cities were reluctant to grant a gravesite for Saddam Hussein's sons.<ref name="guardian1"/>
The decision to bury bin Laden at sea was questioned by terrorists and by some [[9/11]] survivors and the relatives of the victims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fuse.tv/news/articles/?article=0gePetL1FLfCe |title=Muslims furious about Osama sea burial – Daylife |publisher=Fuse.tv |accessdate=May 6, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2011/0503/Osama-bin-Laden-s-burial-at-sea-critics-range-from-9-11-families-to-militants|title=Osama bin Laden's burial at sea: critics range from 9/11 families to militants.|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> Professor Peter Romaniuk of [[John Jay College]] described the burial at sea as a way to forestall further questions. He stated: "Obviously they’re going to be under pressure to show a body or produce further evidence, but this was a way of taking that issue off the table."<ref name=autogenerated2 /> A stated advantage of a burial at sea is that the site is not readily identified or accessed, thus preventing it from becoming a focus of attention or "terrorist shrine".<ref name="ref-41">{{cite news | url = http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2011/05/osama-bin-laden-body-headed-for-burial-at-sea-officials-say.html | title = Osama Bin Laden Body Headed for Burial at Sea, Officials Say | publisher = ABC News | date = May 2, 2011 | accessdate = May 2, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110502113045/http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2011/05/osama-bin-laden-body-headed-for-burial-at-sea-officials-say.html | archivedate = May 2, 2011 | df = }}</ref>
==Theories== {{see also|Reactions to the death of Osama bin Laden}}
===In Pakistan=== Senior Pakistani officials disseminated the theory that no firefight ever took place, and that whoever the U.S. forces captured, they executed him outside the compound, and took his body away on a helicopter.<ref>Yusufzai, Mushtaq (2011-05-04). [http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/05/04/147782.html Bin Laden’s daughter confirms her father shot dead by US Special Forces in Pakistan]. ''Al-Arabiya''. Retrieved 2011-05-04.</ref>
[[Hamid Gul]], the former head of Pakistan's [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI), stated in an interview with [[Cable News Network|CNN]] that he believed bin Laden had died many years ago, and that the official death story given out by the American media was a hoax.<ref name="Gul">{{cite news|url=http://inthearena.blogs.cnn.com/2011/05/05/fmr-pakistani-intel-chief-obama-lying/|title=Former Pakistani intel chief: Obama lying|publisher=CNN|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 8, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, he thinks the American government knew about bin Laden's death for years, "They must have known that he had died some years ago so they were waiting. They were keeping this story on the ice and they were looking for an appropriate moment and it couldn't be a better moment because President Obama had to fight off his first salvo in his next year's election as he runs for the presidential and for the White House and I think it is a very appropriate time to come out, bring this out of the closet."<ref name="Gul"/>
Yet another scenario was reported in an article in the [[Urdu]] newspaper ''[[Ausaf]]'', which quoted military sources as saying, "Bin Laden has been killed somewhere else. But since the US intends to extend the Afghan war into Pakistan, and accuse Pakistan, and obtain a permit for its military's entry into the country, it has devised the [assassination] scenario."<ref name="Guard">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/05/osama-bin-laden-conspiracy-theories|title=Osama bin Laden death: The conspiracy theories|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|first1=Patrick|last1=Kingsley|first2=Sam|last2=Jones|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011|location=London}}</ref>
Bashir Qureshi, who lives close to the compound where bin Laden was shot and whose windows were blown out in the raid, was dismissive. "Nobody believes it. We've never seen any Arabs around here, he was not here."<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/8489304/Osama-bin-Laden-killed-conspiracy-theories-proliferate-in-wake-of-raid.html|title=Osama bin Laden killed: conspiracy theories proliferate in wake of raid|publisher=Telegraph | location=London|date=May 3, 2011}}</ref>
===In Iran=== A number of Iranians said they believed that bin Laden was working with the U.S. during the entire war on terror. Ismail Kosari, an Iranian MP, said that bin Laden "was just a puppet controlled by the [[Zionist]] regime in order to present a violent image of Islam after the [[September 11 attacks]]", and that his death "reflects the passing of a temporary US pawn, and symbolizes the end of one era and the beginning of another in American policy in the region".<ref name="Iran"/> Another MP, Javad Jahangirzadeh, said he believed that it was the U.S. that had carried out the terrorist attacks, and bin Laden was the main source of help. He stated, "The West has been very pleased with bin Laden's operations in recent years. Now the West was forced to kill him in order to prevent a possible leak of information he had, information more precious than gold."<ref name="Iran">{{cite news |title=Iran’s reaction to Osama death ranges from skepticism to conspiracy theories|author= |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/141350/20110504/iran-us-osama-israel.htm|newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=May 4, 2011|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref>
Iranian President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] said "I have exact information that bin Laden was held by the American military for sometime... until the day they killed him he was a prisoner held by them," in a live interview on Iranian state television.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Bin-Laden-was-a-US-prisoner-before-being-killed-Iran/articleshow/8354870.cms |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822220614/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Bin-Laden-was-a-US-prisoner-before-being-killed-Iran/articleshow/8354870.cms |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-08-22 |title=Bin Laden was a US prisoner before being killed: Iran |publisher=Times of India }}</ref>
===In Turkey=== Berkan Yashar, a Turkish politician, stated that bin Laden died of natural causes on June 26, 2006 and was buried. The Americans, he claims, dug out bin Laden's body and displayed it, falsely telling the world that he was killed in an assault.<ref>http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/05/19/242057/osama-bin-laden-died-of-natural-causes/</ref>
===Seymour Hersh=== On May 21, 2015, [[Pulitzer Prize|Pulitzer prize winning]] journalist [[Seymour Hersh]] [[Seymour Hersh#Death of Osama bin Laden|published a 10,000 word report]] (later a book -- ''The Killing of Osama bin Laden'') challenging most aspects of the [[Death of Osama bin Laden#Operation Neptune Spear|official account of Osama's death]].<ref name="Seymour M. Hersh"/><ref name="KObL-Hersh">The story was later released as a book. {{cite book|last1=Hersh|first1=Seymour M.|title=The Killing of Osama bin Laden|date=2016|publisher=Verso}}</ref> Among other things, the report claims that the Pakistani [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI) had kept bin Laden under house arrest at Abbottabad since 2006, and that when the US discovered this Pakistani Army chief [[Pervez Kayani]] and ISI director [[Ahmad Shuja Pasha]] helped the U.S. in killing, not capturing bin Laden.<ref name="hersh"/><ref name="The Independent"/> Hersh's U.S. and Pakistani intelligence sources stated that the U.S. had learned of bin Laden's location through a "walk-in", a former ISI officer who came to the US embassy in Islamabad in 2010<ref name="NYRoB-29-9-2016"/> seeking the $25 million reward, and not through tracking a courier. This claim had been previously reported by R.J. Hillhouse and was confirmed afterwards by NBC news.<ref name=hersh /><ref name="intercepthersh"/><ref name="NBChersh"/> The White House denied Hersh's report.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="Washington Post"/>
Pakistani journalist [[Ahmed Rashid]] in the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'' finds the cooperation between the CIA and ISI that Hersh describes "inconceivable", in part because 2011 was "the worst year in US-Pakistan relations since the late 1980s" and "hatred and mistrust" between the CIA and ISI was "acute"—something Hersh does not mention in his article/book.<ref name="NYRoB-29-9-2016"/> Among the incidents that occurred in Pakistan in the months before the killing of bin Laden were the killing of two Pakistanis by [[Raymond Allen Davis incident|Raymond Davis]] a CIA contractor; numerous death threats against the Islamabad CIA station chief after his name was leaked (purportedly by the ISI); the cessation of the issuing of visas for US officials, following which the entire US consulate in Lahore was shut down and moved to Islamabad over concerns about security;<ref name="NYRoB-29-9-2016">{{cite journal|last1=Rashid|first1=Ahmed|title=Sy Hersh and Osama bin Laden: The Right and the Wrong [complete article behind paywall]|journal=New York Review of Books|date=September 29, 2016|volume=63 |issue=14|pages=30, 32|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/2016/09/29/sy-hersh-osama-bin-laden-right-and-wrong/|accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref> increased US anger over the refusal of Pakistan to exert pressure on the Taliban and Haqqani group; the death of 40 Pakistanis including many civilians and later 24 Pakistani soldiers from US drone strikes, the cut off of US supplies to Afghanistan by Pakistan.<ref name="NYRoB-29-9-2016"/> Further adding to the implausibility of Hersh's theory, according to Rashid, is the unlikeliness that either the US would have "calmly accepted" Pakistan's hiding/protecting bin Laden, or that the dozens of Pakistani military, police, fire and bureaucrats—whose silence/complicity would have been required for a successful conspiracy—would have cooperated with the American incursion. While there was little or no disapproval by the Pakistan public over Bin Laden's long residency in Pakistan, the US attack on the compound of bin Laden was so unpopular that just the failure of the military to detect and go after the US helicopters ignited outrage among the media, the public and the civilian government.<ref name="NYRoB-29-9-2016"/>
Andrew Anthony in ''[[The Guardian]]'' called Hersh's theories "forceful but unconvincing".<ref name="guardian-18-4-2016">{{cite news|last1=Anthony|first1=Andrew|title=The Killing of Osama bin Laden by Seymour M Hersh – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/18/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden-review-seymour-m-hersh-abbottabad-syria-sarin-al-nusra-government|accessdate=6 October 2016|agency=The Guardian|date=18 April 2016}}</ref> [[Zach Dorfman]] in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called Hersh's judgment "mixed, at best". (Rashid, Anthony, and Dorfman were also skeptical of another theory expounded in Hersh's book—that the [[Ghouta chemical attack]] that killed hundreds of Syrian civilians where instigated not by the Syrian government, but by rebels aided by Turkey working as [[agents provocateurs]], blaming the Syrian government in hopes of forcing the Obama administration to enter the war against the government.<ref name="dorfman">{{cite news|last1=Dorfman|first1=Zach|title=Review 'The Killing of Osama Bin Laden' by Seymour Hersh details a grave threat to our democracy|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/la-ca-jc-0417-killing-bin-laden-20160417-story.html|accessdate=6 October 2016|agency=Los Angeles Times|date=14 April 2016}}</ref>)
===Internet=== [[Facebook]] groups formed discussing a rumor, in what has been dubbed the "death hoax".<ref name="telegraph1"/><ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=http://www.kwch.com/la-fg-bin-laden-conspiracy-20110503,0,1392179.story|title=Bin Laden's sea burial fuels conspiracy theories|publisher=kwch}}</ref> Some blogs theorised that the raid and killing were faked, in a conspiracy to attempt to deflect questions about [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|President Obama's citizenship]], or to boost Obama's approval ratings and guarantee his popularity during the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 U.S. presidential election]].<ref name="autogenerated3"/>
===Others=== In 2002, the FBI's top counter-terrorism official, Dale Watson, said, "I personally think he [Osama bin Laden] is probably not with us anymore."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1819280,00.html#ixzz1NQHsnLfQ | work=Time | title=Is Osama bin Laden Dying ... Again? | date=June 30, 2008}}</ref> [[Opposition to the War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Anti-war]] activist [[Cindy Sheehan]] stated "If you believe the newest death of OBL, you’re stupid".<ref>Geraghty, Jim (2011-05-02). [http://www.nationalreview.com/campaign-spot/266231/cindy-sheehan-if-you-believe-newest-death-obl-youre-stupid Cindy Sheehan: ‘If you believe the newest death of OBL, you’re stupid.’]. ''National Review''. Retrieved 2011-05-02.</ref><ref name="IBT"/> Sheehan further stated on her Facebook page, "The only proof of [bin Laden] being dead again that we were offered was Obama telling us that there was a DNA match between the man killed by the Navy SEALs and OBL. Even if it is possible to get DNA done so quickly, and the regime did have bin Laden DNA lying around a lab somewhere – where is the empirical proof?"<ref name="Travis">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/05/05/birthers.deathers/?hpt=C1|title='Deathers' take over where 'birthers' left off |publisher=[[CNN International]]|first=Shannon|last=Travis|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref>
On [[Russia Today]], radio host [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]] claimed that bin Laden had been dead for nearly ten years, and that his body had been kept in liquid nitrogen so that it can be used as a propaganda tool at a future politically expedient time. In 2002, he claimed that an anonymous White House source had told him that bin Laden "is frozen, literally frozen and that he would be rolled out in the future at some date".<ref name="ev"/> In a separate interview in 2002, [[Steve Pieczenik]] told Jones that bin Laden had been dead for months.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/report-of-bin-ladens-death-spurs-questions-from-conspiracy-theorists/2011/05/02/AF90ZjbF_story.html|title=Report of bin Laden’s death spurs questions from conspiracy theorists|publisher=''[[Washington Post]]''|first=Emily|last=Wax|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> Jones also pointed to similar comments made by former Secretary of State [[Madeleine Albright]] in 2003, "Yes we have been told by intelligence that they’ve got him, Bush may roll him out but because they exposed that at the election they didn’t do it".<ref name="ev">{{cite web|url=http://www.economicvoice.com/alex-jones-claims-bin-laden-mission-is-a-fake/50019671#axzz1LOEJW1a7|title=Alex Jones claims Bin Laden ‘mission’ is a fake|publisher=Economic Voice|first=Richard|last=Davis|date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> Jones further voiced doubts about the official story of bin Laden's death on his radio show telling his listeners, "My friends, this is a complete and total hoax."<ref name="Travis"/>
The Iranian network [[Press TV]] interviewed [[Webster Tarpley]] and Stephen Lendman, who both doubted the official story of bin Laden's death. Tarpley said he believed bin Laden had been dead for a long time. He also claimed that the public was deceived by a staged announcement.<ref name="PressTV">{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/178338.html|title=US seeks to Balkanize Mideast|publisher=Press TV|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> Both Tarpley and Lendman suggested that Obama's announcement was also an excuse to involve the United States in wars with Pakistan and Middle Eastern nations.<ref name="PressTV"/>
[[Andrew Napolitano]], the host of the [[Fox Business]] program ''[[Freedom Watch]]'', said bin Laden's death could not be verified and insinuated that Obama was using the death of bin Laden to save his "lousy presidency."<ref>CNN: [http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-05/politics/birthers.deathers_1_bin-deathers-radio-host?_s=PM:POLITICS 'Deathers' take over where 'birthers' left off.] May 5, 2011.</ref> An article in ''[[Mediaite]]'' criticized Napolitano's remarks, opining that "such conspiracy talk is ultimately beneath Napolitano and his often enlightened discussions."<ref>{{cite news|last=Schneider|first=Matt|title=Judge Napolitano On Bin Laden’s Death: Is Obama ‘Pulling A Fast One’ To Save ‘Lousy Presidency’?|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/judge-napolitano-on-bin-laden-is-obama-pulling-a-fast-one-to-save-lousy-presidency/|newspaper=Mediaite|date=03-05-11}}</ref>
Canadian deputy Leader of the Opposition and MP, [[Thomas Mulcair]], stated in an interview with [[CBC Television]] that "I don't think from what I've heard that those pictures [of bin Laden's body] exist".<ref>{{cite news |title=Conspiracy theory: NDP deputy leader Mulcair doubts U.S. has bin Laden photos |author= |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gsjUBZTF0SjtjJdJ_aD4_7gqlbEQ?docId=6758076 |newspaper=[[The Canadian Press]] |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> His remarks were picked up by dozens of U.S. media outlets,<ref name="NP">{{cite news|last=Kaszor|first=Daniel|title=NDP MP Thomas Mulcair questions Bin Laden pictures|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/05/04/ndp-mp-thomas-mulcair-questions-bin-laden-kill/|newspaper=National Post|date=04-05-11}}</ref> and criticized by various Canadian politicians.<ref name="NP"/><ref name="TOStar">{{cite news|last=Press|first=The Canadian|title=Conspiracy theory: NDP deputy leader Mulcair doubts U.S. has bin Laden photos|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/985972--conspiracy-theory-ndp-deputy-leader-mulcair-doubts-u-s-has-bin-laden-photos|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=04-05-11}}</ref><ref name="CBC">{{cite news|last=Payton|first=Laura|title=NDP deputy leader doubts bin Laden photos exist|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/story/2011/05/04/pol-mulcair-osama.html|newspaper=CBC|date=04-05-11}}</ref><ref name="GM">{{cite news|last=Ibbitson|first=John|title=NDP’s deputy leader doubts existence of bin Laden photos|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ndps-deputy-leader-doubts-existence-of-bin-laden-photos/article2010535/|newspaper=Globe and Mail|date=04-05-11|location=Toronto}}</ref>
An official statement from the [[Taliban]] stated that the lack of photos or video footage is suspicious, as their own sources close to bin Laden had not confirmed or denied his death, and that "when the Americans killed [[Dadullah|Mullah Dadullah]] (Taliban’s chief military commander) they publicly showed the footage".<ref name="IExpress">{{cite news |title=Conspiracy Theories |author= |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/Conspiracy-Theories/786136/ |newspaper=[[Indian Express]] |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref>
== Related conspiracy theories == Numerous other conspiracy theories relating to bin Laden's death that were discussed include: *That bin Laden had been killed a number of years prior in the [[Tora Bora]] mountains, but that this information had been kept secret to encourage continued support for the [[war on terror]].<ref name="IBT">{{cite news |title=Osama photo decision fuels conspiracy theories |author= |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/141402/20110504/osama-photo-decision-fuels-conspiracy-theories.htm |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref><ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/8488472/Osama-bin-Laden-dead-time-for-the-royal-wedding-conspiracy-theories.html|title=Osama bin Laden dead: time for the royal wedding conspiracy theories|author=Caroline Gammell|publisher=Telegraph|location=London|date=May 3, 2011}}</ref> *That bin Laden died much earlier than reported, and the announcement of bin Laden's death was delayed, so as not to clash with the festivities surrounding the [[wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]].<ref name="telegraph"/> *That the announcement of bin Laden's death was timed to conflict with and take [[Donald Trump]]'s ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 11)|Celebrity Apprentice]]'' off the air, to punish Trump for publicly questioning the authenticity of Barack Obama's birth certificate.<ref name="Guard"/>

''Pagibang Damara'' is a festival in [[San Jose City, Nueva Ecija]] wherein its people celebrates to give thanks for a good harvest in line with their celebration of the City Fiesta on the second or third week of April every year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nueva Ecija Festivals|url=http://www.visitmyphilippines.com/index.php?title=NuevaEcija&func=all&pid=4490&tbl=0|publisher=Department of Tourism}}</ref>
==History==
[[File:Damara or Farmer's Shed.jpg|thumb|Damara]] A ''damara'' is a [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] word for a shelter or a shed made of [[bamboo]] and [[Nypa fruticans|nipa]] that was built on ricefields as a protection for farmers from the sun or rain during planting and harvesting seasons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Festivals in Nueva Ecija|url=http://www.mysmartschools.ph/web/gintoanginaani/f%20pagibang%20damara.htm|publisher=Ginto ang Inaani}}</ref> Farmers and landlords particularly in the city of San Jose many years ago are building this shelter before the planting season and they demolish ''(ginigiba)'' it after the harvest time as they celebrates together for the bountiful harvest. This is where the word ''Pagibang Damara'' (shed ready to be demolished) was adopted by the people of San Jose City, [[Nueva Ecija]] as they celebrates and gives thanks for their good harvest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://punto.com.ph/data/pdf/vol5no83.pdf|newspaper=Punto|date=November 23–24, 2011|title=Trade officials upbeat on Ecija SMEs}}</ref>
===Present time===
Today,the people of San Jose City now celebrates together as one big family unlike the older days which the people celebrates separately. The after-harvest celebration has become multi-sectoral effort wherein it is funded and collectively prepared from contributions both public and private sectors and was celebrated with street dancing, beauty contests, tourism and trade fair, awarding ceremonies and cultural shows.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sy|first=Junjun|title=Mga kabataan, nagpatalbugan sa streetdancing sa Pandawan Festival sa Nueva Ecija|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/221329/ulatfilipino/dagupan/mga-kabataan-nagpatalbugan-sa-streetdancing-sa-pandawan-festival-sa-nueva-ecija|newspaper=GMA News|date=May 12, 2011}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | image = Pawprints of Katrina cover.jpg | name = ''Pawprints of Katrina'' | author = [[Cathy Scott]] | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[Howell Book House]] | location = | release_date = June 2008 | genre = [[Nonfiction]], [[Natural disasters]] | media_type = Hardcover, Kindle | pages = 288 | isbn = 978-0-470-22851-7 | oclc = }}
'''''Pawprints of Katrina: Pets Saved and Lessons Learned''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book written by [[author]] and [[journalist]] [[Cathy Scott]] that documents the author's experience with an animal welfare group and the rescue and reunions of lost animals with their owners in the [[Gulf region]]. The book, with a foreword by [[actor]] [[Ali MacGraw]], was released in August 2008 on the third anniversary of [[Hurricane Katrina]].
More than 200 stories with photos by [[Clay Myers (photographer)|Clay Myers]] detail rescues, examinations, treatment, reunions, and follow-up care by volunteers.
==Summary== The book begins on September 11, 2005, at a freeway off-ramp used as a boat launch, with [[New York City Parks Enforcement Patrol|New York City Parks Enforcement]] (Search & Rescue Team) Department's Captain Scott Shields, known for the efforts of his search-and-rescue dog, Bear, at the World Trade Center on 9/11.
An excerpt from that chapter describes the moment: "Before we set out on a boat to look for stranded pets, the captain asked us to take a moment to remember those lost on 9/11. There, standing amidst the rubble of Hurricane Katrina with the black water just a few feet from us, we bowed our heads, and not a sound was heard. No cars. No lawnmowers. No birds. No planes. No trains. No voices. Not even the couple of dogs rescued and then tied with leashes to the off-ramp railing, awaiting transport, uttered a sound. It was as if, at that brief but somber point in time, they, too, acknowledged the loss of life. It was a poignant moment, observing those lost in the largest terrorist attack on American soil while we were in the thick of rescuing animals in the wake of the biggest natural disaster in U.S. history. The Crescent City was devoid of life, except for those of us out rescuing that day and, of course, the animals left behind."
A story included in the book about Red, a partially paralyzed [[pit bull|pit-bull terrier]], was covered by [[CNN]]'s [[Anderson Cooper]].<ref>[http://www.cnnstudentnews.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0602/27/acd.01.html CNN, "Hurricane Katrina: Six Months Later," February 27, 2006]</ref> A gray cat whose owner drove 10 hours to reunite with his cat and covered in the book was featured by ''[[Dateline NBC]]''.<ref>[http://news.bestfriends.org/index.cfm?page=specialreports&catid=04061773-BDB9-396E-9001EF6EC01318A4&mode=entry&entry=5C084A02-BDB9-396E-99F051AC6BD8F0CB&stid=2 Best Friends news site, "Dateline in the reuniting business," September 15, 2005]</ref>
==Reception== Reviewer Steve Donoghue noted, in ''[[Open Letters Monthly|Open Letters: A Monthly Arts and Literature Review]]'', "...this will certainly be the definitive account of Katrina animal rescue."<ref>[http://www.ecademy.com/module.php?mod=extprofile&fid=14280 ''Open Letters Monthly'', "Review: Pawprints of Katrina," June 20, 2008 (scroll down)]</ref>
The ''Canada Free Press'' wrote that "''Pawprints of Katrina'' tells the inspiring story of the fate of the abandoned pets, some ending in tragedy, many in against-all-odds happy endings."<ref>[http://canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/4024 ''Canada Free Press'' "Pawprints of Katrina will leave pawprints on your heart," July 19, 2008]</ref>
''Book Hound'''s review said, "An experienced rescuer herself, Scott conducted amphibious reporting on the ground and in boats, so her book makes you feel like a firsthand witness to history, as animals are saved and the lucky ones get to be reunited with their people."<ref>[https://www.fetchdog.com/blogs/bookhound/General/pawprints_of_katrina_pets_saved ''Book Hound'' review, "Pawprints of Katrina: Pets Saved and Lessons Learned," June 2, 2008]</ref>
Reviewer Justin Moyer with ''[[Washington City Paper]]'' recommended the book on his Katrina reading list.,<ref>[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/artsdesk/books/2009/09/22/3-katrina-books-recommended/ ''Washington CityPaper'', ArtsDesk, "Three Katrina Books Recommended," September 22, 2009]</ref> as did the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-07-20/features/0807160205_1_show-dogs-howell-book-house-foster ''Chicago Tribune'', Unleashed, July 20, 2008 (scroll down)]</ref> It was on Sacramento Public Library's "Suggested Reading List" for 2010.<ref>[http://www.saclibrary.org/?pageId=975 [[Sacramento Public Library]], "One Book Sacramento," 2010]</ref> And the ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]'' recommended it for spring reading.<ref>[http://www.tampabay.com/features/pets/article432152.ece ''Tampa Bay Times'', "Curl up with a furry companion and book," March 27, 2008]</ref>
''[[The Times-Picayune]]'' columnist Susan Larson reviewed the book, writing, "Scott ends her tale of this 'remarkable collaborative effort' on a note of hope: Katrina raised awareness about how important it is to incorporate caring for animals in disaster planning, and she offers helpful suggestions for pet disaster preparedness."<ref>[http://blog.nola.com/susanlarson/2008/06/bookshelves_are_bursting_with.html ''Time-Picayune'', "This week in the Reading Life: Bookshelves are bursting with great stories -- and portraits -- of our four-legged friends" (scroll down to ''Pawprints of Katrina'' review), June 25, 2008]</ref>
The author spoke at the 2008 [[National Book Festival]] in Washington, D.C., reading from ''Pawprints of Katrina'' on the [[National Mall]].<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/today/cyberlc/feature_wdesc.php?rec=4423 Featured speaker, 2008 National Book Festival, ''Pawprints of Katrina'' reading]</ref> She also appeared on [[KSFR]]'s Santa Fe Radio Cafe in November 2008 while there for a ''Pawprints'' book event with MacGraw.<ref>[http://www.santaferadiocafe.org/podcasts/?p=480 KSFR, Santa Fe Radio Cafe author interview, November 20, 2008]</ref>
Photographer Myers was awarded "Best Spot News Photo Coverage" from the [[Nevada Press Association]] for the book's cover photo included in a first-person account by Scott in ''Las Vegas CityLife''.<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Sep-17-Sun-2006/news/9645999.html ''Las Vegas Review-Journal'', "Nevada Press Association winners," September 17, 2006]</ref><ref>[http://www.lasvegascitylife.com/articles/2005/10/22/local_news/news03.txt ''Las Vegas CityLife'', "Pet project: Local author and freelance journalist finds her calling on the Gulf Coast," October 22, 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120910120031/http://www.lasvegascitylife.com/articles/2005/10/22/local_news/news03.txt |date=September 10, 2012 }}</ref>

{{Infobox film festival | name = Gershman Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival (GPJFF) | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | predecessor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1981}} | disestablished = | successor = | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = Gershman Y | number = | date = | language = | website = {{URL|https://pjff.org/}} | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} The '''Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival''' (also known as the '''Gershman Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival''' ('''GPJFF'''))<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/news/the-oral-tradition-of-film-gershman-philadelphia-jewish-film-festival/article_9ae1e532-dda3-11e8-80b3-f3d7cbf54ae9.html|title=‘The oral tradition of film’: Gershman Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival prepares for its 38th season|first=Andrea ||last=Cantor|date=November 1, 2018|work=[[Philadelphia Weekly]]}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www2.philly.com/philly/entertainment/celebrities/gershman-y-philadelphia-jewish-film-festival-20180521.html|title=Gershman Y rebrands, will move from building of 95 years|first=Nick|last=Vadala|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=May 21, 2018}}</ref> is an annual [[film festival]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], in the United States that presents movies and film-related programs about the Jewish experience, culture, values, and legacy.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6hHRDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT61&dq=%22Philadelphia+Jewish+Film+Festival%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiAnuLpwfveAhXynuAKHX1eAkkQ6AEISDAF#v=onepage&q=%22Philadelphia+Jewish+Film+Festival%22&f=false|title=100 Things to Do in Philadelphia Before You Die|first=Irene Levy|last=Baker|year= 2016|publisher=Reedy Press LLC|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
==Organization== The Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival is organized and hosted by the Gershman Y, an arts and culture [[nonprofit organization]] that has its roots in the Philadelphia Young Men's Hebrew Association that was established in 1875, and offers cultural and artistic events.<ref>Linda Nesvisky (2010). [https://books.google.com/books?id=aa0jCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21&dq=%22gershman+y%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj8mtXN-vzeAhUS16wKHUGSDf8Q6AEINDAC#v=onepage&q=%22gershman%20y%22&f=false ''Jewish Philadelphia: A Guide to Its Sights & Stories,''] [[Arcadia Publishing]].</ref><ref>Liz Spikol (May 23, 2018). [http://jewishexponent.com/2018/05/23/goodbye-gershman-y-arts-org-to-move-change-its-name/ "Goodbye, Gershman Y: Arts Org to Move, Change its Name,"] ''[[The Jewish Exponent]]''.</ref> In November 2018 the Gershman Y switched its focus to center exclusively on film.<ref>Selah Maya Zighelboim (November 2, 2018). [http://jewishexponent.com/2018/11/02/gershman-philadelphia-jewish-film-festival/ "Gershman Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival Holds 38th Season,"] ''The Jewish Exponent''.</ref>
Olivia Antsis is the executive artistic director of the festival, as of 2018.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://www2.philly.com/philly/entertainment/movies/philadelphia-jewish-film-festival-2018-20181031.html|title=Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival 2018: Movies worth seeing this year|date=October 31, 2018|first=Shaun |last=Brady|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer}}</ref> Bill Chenevert is the director of public relations and marketing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/news/making-movies-cool-again-upcoming-pjff-balances-honoring-the-past/article_d7509bd2-b39f-11e7-9767-4bd0d340601e.html|title=Making movies cool again: Upcoming PJFF balances honoring the past and appealing to Millennials|first=Andrea |date= October 17, 2017|last=Cantor|work=Philadelphia Weekly}}</ref><ref>Kyle Hiller (November 8, 2017). [https://www.metro.us/things-to-do/philadelphia/philadelphia-jewish-film-festival-2017 "6 films you can’t miss at the 2017 Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival,"] ''[[Metro (Philadelphia newspaper)|Metro]]''.</ref>
==History==
The Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival was founded and co-directed by Archie Perlmutter in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmadelphia.festivalgenius.com/2016/films/archieawardwinner_secret_filmadelphia2016|title=Archie Award Winner|website=filmadelphia.festivalgenius.com}}</ref> It is the second-oldest Jewish-specific film festival in the United States, after the [[San Francisco Jewish Film Festival]].<ref name="auto1"/>
Among other notable winners, ''[[Draft:Heading Home (2018 film)|Heading Home: The Tale of Team Israel]]'' won the Best Documentary Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival CineMondays 2018, ''[[A Bag of Marbles (2017 film)|A Bag of Marbles]]'' won the Best Narrative Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival 37, ''[[My Hero Brother]]'' won the Best Documentary Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival 37, ''[[Fanny's Journey]]'' won the Best Narrative Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival CineMondays 2017, ''[[The Origin of Violence]]'' won the Best Narrative Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival 36, and ''[[The People vs. Fritz Bauer]]'' won the Best Documentary Audience Award at the Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival CineMondays 2016.<ref>[https://pjff.org/audience-award-winners/ "Audience Award Winners,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival.</ref><ref>[https://nyblueprint.com/heading-home-tale-team-israel-0 "Heading Home: The Tale of Team Israel,"<!-- Bot generated title -->] ''The New York Blueprint''.</ref>
In November 2018 the festival had its 38th annual season.<ref name="auto"/> The festival took place over 19 days, showing 39 films from 12 countries in 11 theaters.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="auto2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://pjff.org/|title=Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival - The Gershman Y|publisher=Philadelphia Jewish Film Festival}}</ref>
